contentrichtext.text: {{other uses2|Paul Lévy}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Paul Lévy | image = Paul Pierre Levy 1886-1971.jpg | image_size = 200px | caption = Paul Pierre Lévy | birth_date = {{birth date|df=yes|1886|09|15}} | birth_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | death_date = {{death date and age|df=yes|1971|12|15|1886|09|15}} | death_place = [[Paris]], [[France]] | nationality = [[France|French]] | field = [[Mathematics]] | work_institution = [[École Polytechnique]]<br>[[École des Mines]] | alma_mater = [[University of Paris]] | doctoral_advisor = [[Jacques Hadamard]]<br>[[Vito Volterra]] | doctoral_students = [[Wolfgang Doeblin]]<br>[[Michel Loève]]<br>[[Benoît Mandelbrot]]<br>[[Georges Matheron]] | known_for = [[Lévy process]]<br>[[Lévy flight]]<br>[[Lévy measure]]<br>[[Lévy's constant]]<br> [[Lévy distribution]]<br>[[Lévy C curve]] | prizes = }} '''Paul Pierre Lévy''' (15 September 1886 – 15 December 1971)<ref name=mactutor>{{MacTutor Biography|id=Levy_Paul}} </ref> was a [[France|French]] mathematician who was active especially in [[probability theory]], introducing [[martingale (probability theory)|martingale]]s and [[Lévy flight]]s. [[Lévy process]]es, [[Lévy measure]]s, [[Lévy's constant]], the [[Lévy distribution]], the [[Lévy skew alpha-stable distribution]], the [[Lévy area]], the [[Lévy arcsine law]], and the [[fractal]] [[Lévy C curve]] are also named after him. Lévy was born in [[Paris]], the son of Lucien Lévy, an Examiner at the [[École Polytechnique]]. Lévy also attended the École Polytechnique and published his first paper in 1905 at the age of 19, while still an undergraduate. His teacher and advisor was [[Jacques Hadamard]]. After graduation he spent a year in military service and then studied for three years at the [[École des Mines]], where he became a professor in 1913.<ref name=mactutor /> During [[World War I]] Lévy conducted mathematical analysis work for the French artillery. In 1920 he was appointed Professor of Analysis at the École Polytechnique, where his students included [[Benoît Mandelbrot]] and [[Georges Matheron]]. He remained at the École Polytechnique until his retirement in 1959, with a gap during World War II after his 1940 firing because of the [[Vichy France|Vichy]] [[Statute on Jews]].<ref name=mactutor /> Lévy received a number of honors, including membership at the [[French Academy of Sciences]] and honorary membership at the [[London Mathematical Society]].<ref name=mactutor /> ==See also== * [[Lévy metric]] * [[Lévy's modulus of continuity]] * [[Lévy–Prokhorov metric]] * [[Lévy's continuity theorem]] * [[Lévy's zero-one law]] * [[Concentration of measure]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{MathGenealogy |id=33053}} * {{MacTutor Biography|id=Levy_Paul}} {{Persondata |NAME= Lévy, Paul |ALTERNATIVE NAMES=Lévy, Paul Pierre |SHORT DESCRIPTION= [[France|French]] [[Mathematician]] |DATE OF BIRTH= 15 September 1886 |PLACE OF BIRTH= [[Paris]], [[France]] |DATE OF DEATH= 15 September 1971 |PLACE OF DEATH= [[Paris]], [[France]] }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Levy, Paul Pierre}} [[Category:École Polytechnique alumni]] [[Category:Mines ParisTech alumni]] [[Category:Corps des mines]] [[Category:1886 births]] [[Category:1971 deaths]] [[Category:20th-century mathematicians]] [[Category:French mathematicians]] [[Category:French Jews]] [[Category:Probability theorists]] [[Category:Researchers in stochastics]]
